messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:38): tries posting somewhere that uses reCAPTCHA, and finds that it rejects two attempts even though the image was pretty clear and he's almost entirely certain he typed the words in correctly
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:56): http://radar.oreilly.com/2009/05/google-announces-support-for-m.html - xmlns:v="http://rdf.data-vocabulary.org "
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:57): Honestly, how hard can it be to get a namespace string right?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:58): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Too hard, it seems :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:58): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: very, very hard, evidently
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:58): I have a special program that hooks into accessibility APIs for inputting namespace URIs
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:59): (I don't use it for anything else. really.)

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:59): (partially because curies doing simple concatenation violates all sorts of assumptions that people have e.g. http://foo/ and http://foo being assumed the same but treated differently)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:00): Looks like Google's updated their help pages to include the trailing "/" now
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:00): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: in fairness, that not a CURIE bug per se. It's an issue that goes back to Namespaces itself
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:01): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Really? Maybe I don't fully understand either then
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:01): Well I guess you just mean that a namespace has to be a literal string
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:01): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: xmlns='http://foo' and xmlns='http://foo/' are distinct namespaces ever since Namespaces
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:01): notes that people may make exactly the same mistakes in mistyping HTML5 microdata itemprop values
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:02): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: not if the vocabulary designer has the good sense not to mint URI-based vocabularies
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:06): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: People mistype non-URI strings too
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:06): So, maybe not exactly the same mistakes
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:06): but mistakes with the same effects :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:07): not quite the same effect
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:07): it'll break the one occurrence
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:07): not the whole page

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:07): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I see that as an argument to bring microdata into the sphere of validation instead of keeping it as an anything goes zone with possibly 'spurious triples'

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:07): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I think it is a usability issue to use strings that people expect to behave in one way (like they do in their browser address bar) in a context where they are treated entirely differently (as a pure literal)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:16): As far as I can tell, the biggest problem with Google's microformats/RDFa support is that they don't provide any way to test it, so it's impossible to tell whether you've got it right or not
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:19): (...where "you" is a person who's tried to mark up data on their page)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:22): I want to test what happens if
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:22): 1) I don't declare the prefix v
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:22): 2) I declare it to another URI
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:22): 3) I declare the right URI to be bound to another prefix
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:24): Considering that Y! hard-coded some prefixes, I think it's too early to say that Google hasn't done the same
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (12:32): is there an example html5 vcard anywhere?
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (12:33): wants to make sure he's reading microdata stuff correctly
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:36): c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d: There isn't one yet, as far as I'm aware
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (12:40): not sure whether/where to use item= or itemprop=
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:43): <div item=vcard> and then everything else is itemprop
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:43): as far as I can tell
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:44): (The spec says "vcard" is a (predefined) type, and everything else is a (predefined) property name)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:45): FWIW I think itemprop is a terrible name
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:45): and that seems like one good reason why
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (12:45): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: that's what i thought, too
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:45): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Got any better suggestions? :-)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:47): propertyname is rather long
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (12:47): was originally property...changed to itemprop shortly thereafter (why? i dunno)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:48): c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d: Because property has theoretical conflicts with future versions of RDFa
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (12:48): makes sense
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:59): c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d: http://junkyard.damowmow.com/387
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:59): except s/property/itemprop/
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (13:01): was pondering how to do include-pattern sorta things
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:01): c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d: subject="" is the only way of doing include-like things yet
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:01): i was thinking of adding <ref/> in a future version
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:01): but probably not in html5
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (13:02): hmmm....interesting
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (13:06): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: might subject being possibly plural work?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:07): how do you mean?
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (13:08): eg...any org name up on a site's header....being able to be used in multiple vcards further down the page
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (13:10): or single vcard being used on multiple calendar enties...that sorta thing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:12): for the latter i think <ref> makes more sense
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:12): <div item=vcard id=me>...</div> <div item=calendar><meta itemprop=owner object=me>...</div>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:12): (if we eventually add it)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:12): and for the former, well... use <meta>, i guess
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:13): do we have any other attributes that take space-separated lists of ids?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:13): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: that's more or less what <Ref> would be
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (13:15): only html profile for GRDDL, that i'm aware of, off type of my head.....,.and that's meta now anyway
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:19): likes how Vodafone has developed open source Linux software in Python for their devices
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:19): (It's not officially supported, but it seems much better than what the other mobile providers have done on Linux (i.e. nothing, as far as I can tell))
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:21): likes how Vodaphone have developed Linux software for the mobile broadband thing he has
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (13:21): no Android apps site out there yet? ;)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:21): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: That's the specific software I'm thinking of :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:21): Too bad I can't get it to actually work, though
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:21): is starting to get a headache from the iCalendar spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:23): i like how vcard and icalendar are almost compatible but not quite
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:23): e.g. they have subtly different formats for times and dates

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:23): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: It seems to both work and not work for me. The whole UI seems to be broken. The actual part that allows me to connect to the internet seems to work
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:23): or e.g. how iCalendar requires the PRODID line but vcard doesn't
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:24): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I managed to connect without that software at all, just using normal PPP stuff, so that's alright
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:25): It's a small miracle that calendaring apps interoperate at all
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:25): Do calendaring apps actually interoperate at all?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:25): iCalendar isn't that bad
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:26): it's better than many web specs on which we have workable (if not stellar) interop
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:26): doesn't define error handling, but nobody did in the 90s
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:26): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Oh well maybe that's what's working for me. I didn't try without the software because I assumed it would fail
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (13:26): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: latest tryserver builds still for html5 parser?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:27): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: iCal interoperates with Nokia's S60 calendar app and partially interoperates with Ericsson's T series calendaring app
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:27): c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d: the latest are for the HTML5 namespace correctness patch
c3b830f9a769b49d3250795223caad4d (13:28): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: the one in your blog entry crashed horribly on win/xp.....linux was fine, though
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:28): I should probably pull the old links from the blog entries...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:35): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: when you say "RDF quad", do you mean lang/datatype as the fourth item in the tuple?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:35): no, i mean provenance
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:36): the language and datatype annotations are considered part of the object literal
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:43): what's happening with Origin in the IETF?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:47): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: have you addressed all the recent hgroup feedback in the spec? that is, is the outline algorithm stable now?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:49): i have at least 16 messages on the topic that i haven't dealt with yet
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:50): btw if the absolute URL algorithm URIfies, that's a bug
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:50): are you sure it does?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:51): I'm not quite sure, but I read it twice and I think it does
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:51): sounds like a bug
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:51): goes read it the third time
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:51): it might un-INDA and leave the path as IRI
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:51): (which would also be a bug)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:51): it should ToUnicode() imho
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: should script-inserted xml:base be considered in HTML documents?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:53): there's a note that says yes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:53): there's a bug in Gecko, then
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:53): spec says yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:53): the spec goes to some lengths to make base URI changes not be expensive
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:54): Gecko checks document HTMLness and returns early
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:54): if you look at the source, there are comments in a bunch of places about implications certain rules have wrt base URI changes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:54): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: it seems to me that steps 6. and 7.1. modify the URL in the algorithm for resolving
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:56): argh. vCard-RDF uses upper-case local names for properties
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:56): worse, it also used mixed case

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:12): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: send mail to the list (and <email/>), i'm pretty sure we want the absolute url to be an IRI, off-hand. Not sure what the implications are though.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:15): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I might be missing something trivial but the "resolve a url" algorithm takes the url to be resolved + either an absolute url or an element
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:15): But the definiton of "absolute url" just says "if the url resoves onto itself"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:15): which doesn't specify what you are resolving it against
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:16): (those bits in quotation marks are not actual quotes)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:16): it should probably say explicitly that it means "if it resolves onto itself for any input base url" or some such
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:16): again, danc is the guy to talk to here
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:17): he's editing that bit
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:17): ok bed time now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:17): nn
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:17): wonders if the question about whether 'absolute URL' is a datatype or is a property of a string has been raised or resolved yet
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:18): has been wondering something similar
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:18): is currently too lazy to raise it
